title: Open health metrics in Colombia
description: Colombian govt would foster efficiency & self-empowerment, but centralised databases raise concerns over data integrity & value therefrom

f6_assessments.q0: Getting public data onto the block chain so government cannot then hide or change it later could be great for transparency and holding governments to account. It would be nice to see a little more discussion on how data integrity will be ensured prior to posting to the blockchain.
f6_assessments.q1: Success in the project will lie first and foremost in getting the data. The proposers claim to have access to the Columbian government. If so then it is likely they will succeed. It would be nice to have more evidence of this, maybe through a linked-in profile. The budget asked for is relatively small and if successful this could be a very high impact project.
f6_assessments.q2: The success will be relatively easy to judge. the proposers have set some milestones for 6 and 12 months which they have to deliver, against which they can be measured. They have left themselves a lot of leeway as to what data will get published, but they are not asking for a large amount of money and introducing transparency to government data is a worthy goal.

f6_assessments.q0: Yes the concept of this proposal does meet the challenge and I can see how this proposal would bring value to both Cardano and Colombian society. However the proposal needs some serious work to make it more understandable. I think there is a language barrier issue here that hopefully the other F6 challenge (multilingual resources) will address. I have emailed the generic IOHK contact to alert the team that there is potential government level collaboration to be fostered here. If a project such as this was implemented successfully it could be a catalyst for governmental adoption globally. I come to this assessment with 10 years experience working in a Public Health Service and have an understanding of the levels of corruption and intense disorganisation that can be found within, also as someone who is learning a second language. I really appreciate the efforts this proposer has made and I'm sorry I can not score it higher.
f6_assessments.q1: I think it is very unlikely that this proposal is ready to bring value to the Cardano ecosystem in its current state. It is an excellent idea and use case but the proposal itself is unstructured and very difficult to understand. There is no Information provided about the proposing team. There is no breakdown or roadmap of how they plan to achieve this project. The proposer references collaboration with the Colombian Secretary of Health but does not provide any evidence.
f6_assessments.q2: Unfortunately this proposal is currently underdeveloped  and doesn't provide a clear & understandable description of problem and solution. This proposal would not be easily auditable in its current form. It is lacking a roadmap or suggestions of metrics for gauging progress. There is no information about the proposers other than stating they are professors at a Colombian University and Government Consultants. I would encourage the proposing team to include more information about themselves, qualifications and provide evidence of claims of working within the Colombian Government. I hope this proposal gets the support and development it needs to action real social good through the use of the Cardano Blockchain.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal addresses the challenge and is very much in line with Cardano's mission, being quite similar to the Ethiopian MoU for Atala Prism and academic tracking. Where this very admirable project missed out on full marks is the absence of an official and publicised engagement with the Sec of Health. A link to an agreement or a news item detailing this cooperation with the government would have been invaluable. Such an undertaking as recording health data requires government oversight which would require analysis on people's privacy rights, accuracy of reported data, etc. Secondly and ironically, one of the rationales given for this project is that government-reported data can not be trusted as it is used to shape the messaging to the voting public. If the Sec of Health is indeed involved, wouldn't that introduce a sense of mistrust and inaccuracy of the source of data desire bing recorded on the Cardano blockchain? If my assessment is false and the intended sources of the information can be trusted despite being government DBs (and its only 'announced' numbers are fudged), then that needs further clarification. Overall, a good undertaking. Good luck.
f6_assessments.q1: There is a high level of confidence that this can be implemented successfully given the bona fides of the proposers; an academic, a public health specialist and a comp scientist. It also claims backing and support of a major University in Colombia and the Columbian Secretary of Health. Access to such resources adds to the chances for success. The 12-moth timeframe with clearly defined activities on every 6-month interval indicates a lot of thought and planning has already been invested in this undertaking and the surprisingly small amount of funding requested means the project will not withdraw a lot from the funding chest. This provides a sense that the end goal is true to the vision of providing a secure, accurate and open access to health data for the Colombian population.
f6_assessments.q2: This assessor adopted a small measure of flexibility in this section and provided a relatively positive score despite the usual development pathways missing. The reason for this is the acknowledgement that the activities defined under the 6th and 12th month roadmaps are purely investigative and analysing in nature, of what metadata needs to be included and from where they will be sourced. Understandably, these activities may not yet provide a clear picture of what can or needs to be developed. It is however comforting to realise the value of what the requested fund represents in Colombia and that the small amount of $12000, in comparison to other proposals with less impact, would be able to recruit a number of developers to build the health data ecosystem. I would recommend given the build would not be conducted until after at least a year has passed, that the proposers either secure Plutus Pioneers (hopefully from Colombia or Sth America) to help in the build or have team members from its dev team to enrol in/watch Lars Brûnes' Plutus class. Good luck and be safe in Colombia.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal aims to work with a sovereign government to build up a decentralized data management system in the health sector. The project has a substantial study component with uncertainty in adaptation. There is a strong need for such initiates to enable Cardano to realize its true potential. There is a well-studied use case for utilizing blockchain for medical records, which can be applied in this case.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers have a close association with Universidad Santo Tomás and claim access to the secretary of the health of Columbia. This makes the proposers highly qualified in pursuing this project and get required government sanctions for testbed implementation.
f6_assessments.q2: The project is for 5 developers to carry out joint identification of data required to be put on blockchain.  The involvement of the Government department is mandatory to have a viable project which brings uncertainty; however, there is a need to pursue this project which has a huge potential to benefit a large population.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is a well-formulated idea for an interesting application of Metadata that has the potential to help the colombian community and foster the adaption of Cardano there. What could be improved though is adressing data security in the proposal, because we are talking of very sensitive data there and security concerns need to be at least adressed there.
f6_assessments.q1: With an university and a public institution in the background, the challenge should be doable.The plan could be more detailed and the proposers could be more transparent about themselves. I was only able to find the main proposer via his name and his university (and he seems up to the task) but it would have been great to know more about the rest of the team. The low costs are appreciated.
f6_assessments.q2: Since we are talking about a public project here, it should be easy to follow it. The success criteria could be a bit mire clear about the exact data worked with in order to make it easier to quantify the success though.

f6_assessments.q0: As stated in this proposal, the problem of untrusted data generated on countries with governments perceived corrupted can be solved with traceable proofs stored in transaction metadata. For that reason, the proposal clearly meets the requirements of this challenge with an impact that could also be replicated to other countries.
f6_assessments.q1: The project is divided in two phases, the first one as a pilot and the second as the expansion as more datasets are aggregated. Feasibility of the first phase looks high since the team is supported by a university and is already engaged with the government. However, the second phase is riskier since it depends on other governmental actors. Overall, the project can be considered feasible with an uncertainty on the second part that may make it longer.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal provides a clear definition of success of each part that can be used for tracing. The fund requested is a minimum part of the total cost of the project since it is mainly supported by a university and the public sector. However there are no well-defined metrics and intermediate milestones.

solution: Store metadata on the blockchain in order to assist better policy-making by criss-crossing tamper-resistant health records & other databases
experience: Project leads have experience w/ databases, BI & understanding of the government structure. Consultants for UPL, Indra & the colombian govt.
